title: The Mission of the Twelve
shortSummary: Matthew 10 records Jesus commissioning His twelve disciples, empowering them to preach, heal, and cast out demons specifically to the lost sheep of Israel. The chapter also prepares them for persecution, emphasizing faithfulness, courage, and the cost of discipleship while assuring God's sovereign care.
timeline: c. AD 27-28 - Early Ministry of Jesus, prior to His crucifixion

keyCharacters.name: Jesus Christ
keyCharacters.description: The Messiah who commissions and empowers the twelve disciples for ministry and instructs them on their mission and the challenges they will face.

keyCharacters.name: Simon Peter
keyCharacters.description: One of the twelve apostles, called first among them, known for his leadership and boldness.

keyCharacters.name: Judas Iscariot
keyCharacters.description: One of the twelve apostles who later betrays Jesus, mentioned here as part of the twelve sent on the mission.

keyCharacters.name: The Twelve Disciples
keyCharacters.description: The group of Jesus’ closest followers who are sent out to preach, heal, and cast out demons, representing the foundation of the early church.

definitions.definition: Evil spiritual beings or demons that Jesus gave the disciples authority to cast out.

definitions.term: Lost sheep of the house of Israel
definitions.definition: A metaphor for the Jewish people who were spiritually lost and in need of the Messiah’s message.
A small bag or wallet used to carry provisions or money, which Jesus instructs the disciples not to take.
A name used for the prince of demons; here it symbolizes the accusations Jesus and His followers would face.
A symbol of suffering and sacrifice; Jesus calls His followers to take up their cross, meaning to accept persecution and hardship for His sake.

outline.heading: Commissioning and Naming the Twelve Apostles
outline.description: Jesus calls and empowers His twelve disciples, giving them authority over unclean spirits and diseases, and lists their names, including Judas Iscariot who will betray Him.

outline.heading: Instructions for the Mission to Israel
outline.description: Jesus sends the twelve out with specific instructions to minister only to the lost sheep of Israel, preaching the kingdom, healing, and relying on God’s provision while discerning worthy hosts.

outline.heading: Warnings of Persecution and Encouragement
outline.description: Jesus warns the disciples of coming opposition, betrayal, and suffering but assures them that the Holy Spirit will guide their words and that they should be wise and innocent.

outline.heading: Cost and Commitment of Discipleship
outline.description: Jesus explains the cost of following Him, including division even among family, and calls for wholehearted allegiance above all relationships, promising eternal reward for those who lose their life for His sake.

outline.heading: Receiving the Disciples and Rewards
outline.description: Jesus teaches that receiving His disciples is equivalent to receiving Him and God the Father, promising rewards even for small acts of kindness done in His name.

application: Trust God’s provision and power as you serve Him, relying on His Spirit rather than your own resources.
Be prepared for opposition and persecution when faithfully proclaiming the gospel, knowing that endurance leads to salvation.
Prioritize your relationship with Christ above all earthly ties, embracing the cost of discipleship with courage and faith.
Show hospitality and kindness to fellow believers and those who serve in ministry, recognizing that God honors such acts.

keyVerses.text: And as ye go, preach, saying, The kingdom of heaven is at hand.
keyVerses.significance: This verse captures the central message of the disciples’ mission: the imminent arrival of God's kingdom.

keyVerses.text: And fear not them which kill the body, but are not able to kill the soul: but rather fear him which is able to destroy both soul and body in hell.
keyVerses.significance: It teaches believers to prioritize reverence for God over fear of earthly threats, emphasizing eternal consequences.

keyVerses.text: And he that taketh not his cross, and followeth after me, is not worthy of me.
keyVerses.significance: This verse highlights the necessity of self-denial and willingness to suffer as essential to true discipleship.

keyVerses.text: He that receiveth you receiveth me, and he that receiveth me receiveth him that sent me.
keyVerses.significance: It affirms the close identification between Jesus, His followers, and God the Father, underscoring the importance of supporting God’s messengers.
